s.text: They wonder whether Gary Bauer is strong enough to resist the urge.

Unable to formulate a precise allegation, one reporter asked Bauer whether his behavior with McClard had been "flirtatious or in any way different from how you interact with other aides" (answer: no).

Unable to formulate a precise allegation, one reporter asked Bauer whether his behavior with McClard had been "flirtatious or in any way different from how you interact with other aides" (answer: no).

Unable to formulate a precise allegation, one reporter asked Bauer whether his behavior with McClard had been "flirtatious or in any way different from how you interact with other aides" (answer: no).

Unable to formulate a precise allegation, one reporter asked Bauer whether his behavior with McClard had been "flirtatious or in any way different from how you interact with other aides" (answer: no).

Monday, a New York Daily News gossip column asked, "What presidential candidate is praying that a former secretary doesn't go public with her claim that he's been having an affair with a twentysomething woman?

Unable to produce allegations of impropriety, reporters asked Bauer in accusatory tones whether he had "met behind closed doors" with the aide, Melissa McClard (answer: yes), and whether Bauer's aides had told him "that people are asking questions [about it] and it's making people uncomfortable."
They should ask the same question of themselves.

Unable to produce allegations of impropriety, reporters asked Bauer in accusatory tones whether he had "met behind closed doors" with the aide, Melissa McClard (answer: yes), and whether Bauer's aides had told him "that people are asking questions [about it] and it's making people uncomfortable."
They should ask the same question of themselves.

Monday, a New York Daily News gossip column asked, "What presidential candidate is praying that a former secretary doesn't go public with her claim that he's been having an affair with a twentysomething woman?

Monday, a New York Daily News gossip column asked, "What presidential candidate is praying that a former secretary doesn't go public with her claim that he's been having an affair with a twentysomething woman?

"Is it possible," a reporter asked Bauer, "that you may have been engaging in behavior that was perfectly innocent [but] in the minds of the people who work for you and respected you was inappropriate, and that perhaps you--as it was put by someone to me--you appeared a little arrogant in refusing to recognize, according to them, their complaints?"
One reporter asked whether Bauer's former secretary had told him, "I wish you wouldn't behave this way with this woman."
